description:
This dataset provides a globally consistent, high-resolution (100 m) coastal typology, derived from satellite imagery and elevation data using a deep learning model. It provides a foundational dataset for coastal-change analysis, erosion assessment, and more broader coastal vulnerability mapping and coastal adaptation in the face of accelerating climate change.

Using a supervised multi-task convolutional neural network, we classified four coastal attributes along the cross-shore profile for nearly 10 million transects from the Global Coastal Transect System (GCTS):
1.  **Sediment Type**: e.g., sandy, gravel or shingle; muddy; rocky; or, no sediment.
2.  **Coastal Type**: e.g., cliffed or steep, sediment plain, wetlands, or dune systems.
3.  **Built Environment**: Presence or absence of human development.
4.  **Coastal Defenses**: Presence or absence of human-made coastal defenses.

The model achieves strong predictive performance (F1 scores: 0.67-0.83). Results show that ~61% of the global coastline consists of soft, potentially erodible sediments. Among sandy, gravel, or shingle coasts, 20% are cliff-backed and 16.5% are located on built-up coasts.

Data are stored in a cloud-optimized, partitioned Parquet format. Tutorials and usage examples are available via the `coastpy` Python library: https://github.com/TUDelft-CITG/coastpy.

Please cite the associated publication when using this dataset:
Calkoen et al., 2025, *Mapping the world's coast: a global 100 m coastal typology derived from satellite data using deep learning*, Earth System Science Data (in review at https://essd.copernicus.org/preprints/essd-2025-388/).

DOI paper: https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-2025-388
DOI dataset: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15599096

data.title: Global Coastal Typology
data.description: Parquet dataset providing a global coastal typology derived from satellite imagery and elevation data.

table:columns.name: transect_id
table:columns.description: Unique identifier for each transect, constructed from coastline, segment, and distance.

table:columns.name: geometry
table:columns.description: Transect origin (Point Geometry) as a Well-Known Binary (WKB) LineString.

table:columns.name: utm_epsg
table:columns.description: EPSG code representing the UTM Coordinate Reference System of the transect.

table:columns.name: bbox
table:columns.description: Bounding box of the transect geometry, defined by minimum and maximum x (longitude) and y (latitude) coordinates.

table:columns.name: quadkey
table:columns.description: Spatial index for the transect origin, following the Bing Maps Tile System.

table:columns.name: continent
table:columns.description: Name of the continent where the transect is located.

table:columns.name: country
table:columns.description: ISO alpha-2 country code for the transect's location.

table:columns.name: common_country_name
table:columns.description: Common name of the country where the transect is located.

table:columns.name: common_region_name
table:columns.description: Common name of the region where the transect is located.

table:columns.name: class:shore_type
table:columns.description: Predicted shore type classification, which describes the material composing the shore (e.g., sandy sediments, rocky formations, or muddy sediments).

table:columns.name: class:coastal_type
table:columns.description: Predicted coastal type classification, which refers to the geomorphological features of the coast, which may be natural (e.g., cliffs, dunes) or human-influenced (e.g., engineered structures).

table:columns.name: class:has_defense
table:columns.description: Boolean flag indicating whether coastal defense structures (e.g., sea walls, breakwaters) are present to protect against erosion and flooding.

table:columns.name: class:is_built_environment
table:columns.description: Boolean flag indicating whether the coastal area is dominated by human-made structures or remains largely natural.

table:columns.name: class:prob_sandy_gravel_or_small_boulder_sediments
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the shore is composed of sandy sediments, gravel, or small boulders. Derived from the shore type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_muddy_sediments
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the shore is composed of muddy sediments. Derived from the shore type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_rocky_shore_platform_or_large_boulders
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the shore consists of rocky platforms or large boulders. Derived from the shore type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_no_sediment_or_shore_platform
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the shore lacks sediment and consists mainly of shore platform features. Derived from the shore type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_cliffed_or_steep
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast is cliffed or steep. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_moderately_sloped
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast is moderately sloped. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_bedrock_plain
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast is characterized by a bedrock plain. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_sediment_plain
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast is characterized by a sediment plain. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_dune
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast contains dune systems. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_wetland
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast includes wetland environments. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_inlet
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast contains an inlet or estuarine feature. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_engineered_structures
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coast includes engineered structures. Derived from the coastal type classification.

table:columns.name: class:prob_has_defense
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that coastal defense structures are present. Complements the binary 'class:has_defense' label.

table:columns.name: class:prob_is_built_environment
table:columns.description: Model confidence (probability between 0 and 1) that the coastal area is built-up or dominated by human-made infrastructure. Complements the binary 'class:is_built_environment' label.

table:columns.name: class:model
table:columns.description: Identifier for the machine learning model used for coastal typology predictions.

table:columns.name: class:datetime_created
table:columns.description: Timestamp indicating when the coastal typology predictions were generated.

sci:citation: Calkoen, F. R., Luijendijk, A. P., Hanson, S., Nicholls, R. J., Moreno-Rodenas, A., De Heer, H., and Baart, F.: Mapping the world's coast: a global 100-m coastal typology derived from satellite data using deep learning, Earth Syst. Sci. Data Discuss. [preprint], https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-2025-388, in review, 2025.
title: Global Coastal Typology

geoparquet-stac-items.title: GeoParquet STAC items
geoparquet-stac-items.description: Snapshot of the collection's STAC items exported to GeoParquet format.
